column46: On a cold February night, RNLI volunteers from Scarborough launched their lifeboat into dark and treacherous conditions. Led by Helm Rudi Barman, they braved breaking 2m waves and whipping force 7 winds to reach Andrew McGeown. They brought him to shore and did everything they could to revive him. Tragically, Andrew was beyond help. Rudi received the RNLI’s Bronze Medal for Gallantry for his leadership, boathandling skills and bravery. ‘I don’t think anything can ever prepare you for a rescue like that,’ he says. ‘It was the most difficult rescue I’ve been on. But it’s something we train for day in, day out. To be recognised with an award like this is a great honour, but it’s not just me. There are many different wheels that work in this station down to the people who have trained me and the crew over the years.’

However it gives no indication of how widespread this is; while I am confident that there are some cultures who would ostracise children with a cleft palate, I would speculate that a material proportion (maybe the majority?) of the children helped were in fact quite happy with their lives before the intervention, and that while the intervention would have been (presumably) viewed positively by the beneficiary and his/her family at the time, would likely have done little to improve their lives (note that this is pure speculation; the charity provides no evidence to confirm or deny this). The rating of 3 assumes that the surgery can on occasions be life-changingly positive, and in other cases would render the beneficiary's life not materially better - more evidence would be needed to justify a higher rating. column59: Getting pets microchipped becomes valuable only when the pet is lost. According to "Frequency of Lost Dogs and Cats in the United States and the Methods Used to Locate Them" (www.mdpi.com/2076-2615/2/2/301/pdf) 15% of dogs are lost, and of those most are found by just searching the neighbourhood - only 14% of that 15% actually benefit from the microchip. In other words, only around 2% of those actually benefit from the chip, so that intervention gets a 1 out of 5 for its impactfulness. Neutering is also a valuable intervention because it stops the dog from breeding, which would be difficult to manage, however this is a qualified opinion, since according to http://www.yourpurebredpuppy.com/health/articles/neutering-male-dog.html , it can triple the risk of obesity, increase the risk of a cancer called hemangiosarcoma, triple the risk of hypothyroidism, increase the risk of geriatric cognitive impairment, and other risks. On balance it's still positive and gets a 4 out of 5. Caring for rehomed dogs is clearly 5 out of 5, since their condition without that care would be terrible.

The way they operate seems good, using a peer education model that seems promising. The use of teenage mothers as staff members also sounds like a strength of the model. The key question is the importance of the cause. I could find little information in the annual report to answer this question. I have tried looking for research to help understand the answer to this, and I can find many journal articles which baldly state/assume that teenage pregnancy is bad, but little to estimate how bad, or high how a priority it should be. When considering the overall assessment of the charity, it will be important to remember that the cost per beneficiary will appear low (around £40 at the moment) because it will reach lots of people, but most of them would not have become teenage parents anyway. The low impactfulness assessment largley also reflects the fact that most of the people in the audience would not have been involved in teenage pregnancy anyway, and hence will come away unaffected

column59: The annual report states that "Prisoners that keep in contact with their families are up to 6 times less likely to re-offend" - this seems incredibly powerful on its own, even ignoring the benefit to the children and families. It would be important to chase up the source of the statistic to see whether the background to the calculation applies in a relevant way to Storybook dads. Gut feel without having seen the original source of the stat is that the effect is probably not a 6-fold improvement in recidivism rates; rather I think that those who are more dedicated to the idea of engaging with Storybook Dads are more likely to be dedicated to not reoffending when they get out. The rating of 3 out of 5 is based on the idea that maintaining a connection with the family can have a positive effect, albeit not a sixfold improvement (as well as the other benefits of the programme, of course). The info at http://www.researchgate.net/publication/269700976_Case_Study_Storybook_Dads seems positive as well. It left me somewhat confused about the reference to profitability though, how does that work? I'm also surprised that the charity can offer the service so cost-effectively - I say this partly because I would have thought that the recordings would need to be checked for the risk that the inmates smuggle out secret messages, and hence the recordings would need to be checked. I have seen no sign of this in the info I've read though.

The ‘digital teacher’ immediately responds on any result that the child has found for his/her exercise. The project is currently reaching almost 25,000 children, and now has funding to roll out further and reach 55,000 children. column59: A video at https://www.sendacow.org/how-we-work shows that before their work, 23% of respondents were confident of being able to provide for their families, with 97% saying that they were confident after doing the training. Not clear how to reconcile this with the fact that only around 20% of those doing the course then "graduate" - I'm inclined to disregard the study shown in the video, as it seems likely that the respondents are biased to respond positively. And what's more, confidence doesn't really mean anything - the important question is whether they actually got a higher income at the end of it. I think the most important question is how big an impact does it make for he 1620 households who "graduate" - do they see a big increase in income? I'm going to guess yes.However the dilution effect means that the overall impact can't be too high - c 20% of the 7,653 beneficiaries will have a (presumably) big improvement lives, others a bit of help, and others minimal impact. Averaging this out to an impact of 3 seems right. More info may arrive, which may change this assessment. Note that a comparison with Bees For Development seems to suggest that BfD is much better, with a lower cost per beneficiary, and without any of the complications that arrive from giving goods to beneficiaries.

Comments and information about impact (even at outputs level) is poor. Could reasonably argue that the accounts say that the charity has zero impact, because the SOFA states (p11) that the expenditure is around two thirds fundraising costs and one third governance expenses, and zero on charitable activities. In reality, this is probably just poor accounting practice, since pages 20-21 seem to indicate that a material sum has been spent on guest speakers/preachers, radio/tv ministry and volunteer expenses. No mention was made of the sale of olive oil, however, nor of the 10 year battle against extradition from Kenya that Gilbert Deya faces, nor of the fact that his wife is guilty of child trafficking, although these facts have gathered more attention elsewhere (http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/charity-commission-investigates-charity-sells-healing-olive-oil/governance/article/1406256 http://www.itv.com/news/london/2016-01-25/archbishop-of-peckham-defiant-after-sting-reveals-fake-cancer-cure-claims/) Several of the cost items look surprisingly high - e.g. interest payable of £137k or legal fees of £85k. The interest of £137k and the depreciation of £54k may in fact be fine, given that the balance sheet seems to indicate that the charity does own property, however this would raise the question of why the charity needed to spend over £100k on rent. Overall, it looks suspicious.

column35: The cup trust has now been all but wound down, however I looked at the most recent set of accounts available, which is a few years old. The activities gave no indication of the number of beneficiaries. In fact, very unusually, it made no meaningful mention of any charitable activity at all - any talk about activity was focused on raising funds. The language was defensive. And the reserves were surprisingly small given the amount of income. When I tried to understand anything about the financial position, I was flummoxed by the fact that the charity received £78.9m, and then "spent" £78.9m on "buying gilts". Bizarrely, after buying the gilts, the money seems to have just vanished, thus breaking a fundamental of accounting (and a rule of how the world works) namely after you buy gilts, you have gilts. The Cup Trust bought gilts and this caused money to disappear. This set of accounts reeked so horrifically that I'm surprised nobody noticed it for so long
